bibl.title: Wiley v. Keokuk. Civil Action
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: Be it remembered, that heretofore, to wit, on the 19th day of August A.D. 1869 Albert Wiley one of the Defendants in the case of Keokuk Chief of the Sac & Troy dridraes - against Charles C. Mix et-al
filed in the office of the Clerk of the District Court of Douglas County his certain made case for the Supreme Court against Keokuk which said made case is no words as follows
Keokuk Chief of the Sae & For Indians against Charles E. Mix, Thomas Muprhy, Albert Wiley Thomas Dorwin & William P. Montogery Defts } Civil Action
In the District Court of Douglas Co. Kan. The said plaintiff on the 19th day of December A.D. 1869 picked in office of the clerk of said District Court his petition the of which is as follows.

The said Keokuk plaintiff complains of the said defendants Charles E. Mix Thomas Muphy, Albert Wiley, Thomas Dorwin and William P. Montgomery for this at the said defendants on the 23rd day of November
A.D. 1868 at Lawrence in the County of Douglas unlawfully and with force assaulted the said plaintiff and Great Cruised wounded and ill treated him and them and there imprisoned him and kept and detained him in prison in the county jail of Douglas County amongst a lot of thieved until other vile characters without any reasonable or probable whatever for the space of one night and two days next following and other things these and there did to the said plaintiff to the damage of the said plaintiff Ten Thousand dollars. Wherefore the said plaintiff prays judgement against the said defendants for the of Ten Thousand dollars ($10.000) his damages so aforesaid sustained.
In the 15th day of February AD 1849 the defendant Albert Wiley filed his answer in said case the body of which answer is as follows.
1er def. And now comes the said Albert Wiley one of said defendants and from separate answer to the
plaintiff petition says that one cach and very Megation there constrained.

2d def. And the said defendant for a second defense to the plaintiff petition says that on and prior to the 23d day of November AD 1868 he was the United States Indian Agent for the Sac & Fox Indians in the State of Kansas and for a long time previous thereto be had as such; That the said plaintiff is one of the Indians of said tribes and pretends to be a chief os said Indians and on the 23d day of November AD 1868 and for a long time previous thereto resided on the lands of said tribes in the county of Franklin in the state of Kansas.

That on or about the 21st day of October AD 1868 this defendant as such Indian Agent received from the said Thomas Murphy who then was the United States superintendent of Indian affairs in the state of Kansas as order of which a copy is hereto attached mankind "A" and make a part of

this answer. This defendant further says that with said order he received a copy of an order given by Charles C. Mix who was then the acting commissioner of Indian affairs for the United States which order is dated October 16th Ad 1868 a copy of said order is hereto attached marked "B" and made a part of this answer. That by the terms of said orders this defendant as such Indian Agent was required to prevent any Indians of said Tribes visitors Washington D.C. and was required by the order of said Murphy to notify said Murphy if any Indians of said Tribes intended visiting said city of Washington.

That on or about the 16th day of November AD 1868 this defendant caused the above mentioned orders to be to the plaintiff and other Indians of said Tribes. That on or about the 19th day of November AD 1868 the defendant informed Thomas Murphy that said plaintiff with others contemplated visiting the city of Washington in violation

of the order of the said Charles C above mentioned, and the aid Murphy time suck vaper intendant of Indian affairs did then order and require this defendant in case said plaintiff should leave the Reserve of said Indians in said county of Franklin for the purpose of giving is Washington is cause him to be arrested and pursuing jail or returned to his Reservation.

That on or amour the 22d day fo November AD 1868 this defendant was informed that said plaintiff with others had left said Reserve in said county of Franklin and was there in the of Lawrence Douglas County Kansas on his way to the city of Washington D.C., in violation of said order above mentioned. That this defendant oon said day went before Hon. William P. Montgomery who then was the states commissioner for the District and State of Kansas and made an affidavit in writing a copy of which is hereto attached marked "C" and made a part of this answer and that on the same day he gave his testimony

as a evident on the nearing of said complaint anymore said commission against the said plaintiff. That the above is a full statement of all that this defendant had to do with said plaintiff or the arrest assault or imprisonment of the said plaintiff.

That this defendant did not arrest touch or imprison said plaintiff, or in any manner interfere with him, and all he did do in the provisions was strictly in accordance with the instructions and orders he had received as above mentioned and which this defendant as on of the United States was bound by law to obey.
Wherefore this defendant asks judgment against the said plaintiff for his costs and that said said as against him may be dismissed.
Copy of Order mentioned in the aforesaid answer marked "A" and make a part of the same.
Office Supt Indian affairs atchison Kansas Oct 23d 1868 Sir. I transmit herewith for

your information and Government a copy of a letter of the 16th inst from Hon Charles C Wise actg commission. You will do all in your power to have the instructions of the actg Commission carried out and should any delegation from our tribe contemplate visiting Washington without special instructions given the Department you would promptly advise this office very Respectfully
Thomas Murphy actively U.S. Indian Agent Sac & Fox agency Kansas.
Copy of Order mentioned in said answer marked B and made a part thereof.
Department of the Interior, office of Indian affairs Washington D.C.
Oct 16th 1868

Sir, I to answer you that as Congress failed is make certain appropriations from which the of delegations of Indians visiting City name heretofore been paid. No delegation from any of the Tribes in your super=

=intendency will be allowed to visit this place during the present pascal year unless specially directed to do so cry this office for the reason that there are no funds at the disposal of the Department that can be used to defray their necessary expenses. You will inform the different agents under you of the foregoing and take present any Indians coming here as may we necessary to accomplish the ovier.
Very Respectfully Thomas Murphy Dept Ind Affairs Atchison Kansas} Charles E. Mix actg Commission
